title: Inside Velvét’s Atelier: Where Luxury is Crafted

content.text: Step into the heart of Velvét — the atelier where luxury is not merely produced, but lovingly crafted by master artisans. Tucked away from the glamour of fashion weeks, this sacred space is where every collection begins its journey from concept to couture.

Founder Ritvik Sharma personally oversees each new line, ensuring that every fabric, finish, and stitch reflects the Velvét promise of excellence. 'Perfection is not optional here; it’s our language,' Sharma states. Every pattern is hand-cut, every lining chosen with precision — because luxury lives in the details.

In the atelier, time slows down. Artisans spend up to 200 hours crafting a single jacket, blending centuries-old embroidery techniques from Lucknow with contemporary Italian tailoring. Each coat, dress, and suit is a harmonious balance between tradition and modern design, elevating everyday garments into timeless heirlooms.

Every piece that leaves the atelier carries a personal touch — from the artisan’s initials discreetly hidden in the seams to the hand-stitched Velvét label that signifies authenticity. 'Our customers aren’t just buying fashion; they’re inheriting a piece of living craftsmanship,' says Sharma.

The journey begins with sourcing. Velvét's fabrics come from handpicked mills in Como, Italy, and local weavers in Varanasi, India. 'We only use wool that breathes, silk that glides, and cotton that feels like second skin,' explains Sharma. Sustainability is key — 70% of the atelier’s materials are now eco-certified, in line with Velvét’s pledge to go 100% sustainable by 2030.

Buttons are crafted from reclaimed seashells, zippers sourced from ethical suppliers, and packaging made from recycled fibers. These small choices echo Velvét’s larger mission: to redefine luxury without compromising the planet.

Velvét’s atelier creations have adorned global icons — from Zendaya’s custom velvet gown at Cannes to BTS’s tailored jackets on tour. Each piece is custom-fitted, reflecting not just the wearer’s measurements but their personality. 'Our atelier doesn’t just dress bodies, it tells stories,' Sharma emphasizes.

Looking ahead, Velvét plans to open its atelier doors to clients through exclusive tours, offering them a rare glimpse into the craftsmanship behind their garments. For Sharma, this is the future of luxury: transparency, tradition, and timelessness, woven together in every thread.
